oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Economic considerations for subclinical ketosis in lactating dairy cattle
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Gohary, K. G.
LeBlanc, S. J.
Lissemore, K. D.
Von Massow, M.
Overton, M. W.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: milk quality
reproductive performance
hyperketonemia
economic losses
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Milk production and reproductive performance can decrease as a result of hyperketonemia in lactating dairy cows. In addition, cows with hyperketonemia are at higher risk of developing a variety of diseases including displaced abomasum, metritis, retained placenta, and clinical ketosis, and are more likely to be culled. The negative impact of hyperketonemia can be observed at both the individual-cow and herd levels. As a result, significant economic losses might be encountered in dairy herds with a high incidence of hyperketonemia.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 2013; 141
